bibl.title: Letter from L. O. Howard to Walter Reed, March 7, 1902

div1.p: Howard responds to Reed's most recent letter, and discusses the notion of insects affecting both humans and domestic animals. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from L. O. Howard to Walter Reed, March 7, 1902
div1.p:
Yours of the 5th has just reached me. The De-
partment has issued no such bulletin recently, but evidently the one
which you mention is No. 5, new series, published in 1896. It is
now quite scarce, but I am sending you a single copy. You will
notice that it confines itself to insects affecting domestic ani-
mals. The word man is not included in the title, and only inci-
dentally here and there through the book are insects which affect
man indicated.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, L. O. Howard Dr. Walter Reed, U. S. A.,
U. S. Army Medical Museum,
City.
ht
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES OF THE UNITED STATES
* 1934 *
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Washington, D. C.
RECORDS OF THE DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE, Bureau of
Entomology and Plant Quarantine.
Three Centimeters
